This map illustrates the areas historically inhabited by the Bororo, an Indigenous people of Brazil, as well as the current Indigenous Lands (TIs) where the Boe Bororo now live, primarily located in the state of Mato Grosso. At the top, the title "Surrounded by the White Man and Fire" suggests the historical and ongoing pressure faced by the Bororo due to colonization and environmental destruction.

The first map, at the top, highlights the area traditionally inhabited by the Bororo, which extended from present-day Mato Grosso into parts of Mato Grosso do Sul and Goi√°s, encompassing important rivers like the Cuiab√° River and the S√£o Louren√ßo River.

In the lower section, the second map presents the currently recognized and demarcated Indigenous Lands (TIs) where the Bororo reside. These are: TI Sangradouro/Volta Grande, TI Perigara, TI Merure, TI Tereza Cristina, TI Jarudore, and TI Tadarimana, all located in Mato Grosso. The TIs are marked in red, showing the drastic reduction in territory that the Bororo have experienced compared to their original lands.

The map also includes a small highlight of the state of Mato Grosso within Brazil, emphasizing the geographic location of the areas mentioned.

The sources cited include historical and ethno-historical works, such as "A Duras Penas: Um Hist√≥rico das Rela√ß√µes entre √çndios Bororo e 'Civilizados' no Mato Grosso," by Renate Brigitte Viertler, as well as an ethno-historical map by Curt Nimuendaj√∫ and the Instituto Socioambiental, which provide context for the reduction and delimitation of Bororo lands over the centuries.
